paragraphs.text: %md ## OML4Py Data Transformation: Normalization and Scaling In this notebook, we demonstrate how to normalize and scale data using OML4Py. We use the customer insurance lifetime value data set which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance. We show how to normalize data usig using z-score (mean and standard deviation), min max scaling, and log scaling. The dataset `CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV` is generated by the `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook, which `MUST` be run before this notebook. --- ##### `IMPORTANT`: The `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook. --- **Note** : when building or applying a model using in-database Oracle Machine Learning algorithms, automatic data preparatio will normalize data automatically as needed by specific algorithms. For instance, see Data Preparation for GLM . Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
OML4Py Data Transformation: Normalization and Scaling

In this notebook, we demonstrate how to normalize and scale data using OML4Py.

We use the customer insurance lifetime value data set which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance.

We show how to normalize data usig using z-score (mean and standard deviation), min max scaling, and log scaling.

The dataset CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV is generated by the "OML Run-me-first" notebook, which MUST be run before this notebook.

IMPORTANT: The "OML Run-me-first" notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook.

Note : when building or applying a model using in-database Oracle Machine Learning algorithms, automatic data preparatio will normalize data automatically as needed by specific algorithms. For instance, see Data Preparation for GLM .

Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

msg.data: OML4Py documentation on Data Summarization: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4py/1/mlpug/summarize-data.html

paragraphs.title: Import python libraries and set display options
paragraphs.text:
%python

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

import pandas as pd
import oml
from oml import automl

pd.set_option('display.max_rows', 500)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)
pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

paragraphs.title: Normalization by z-score - using mean and standard deviation
paragraphs.text:
%python

income_mean = CUST_DF['INCOME'].mean()
income_std = CUST_DF['INCOME'].std()

CUST_DF = CUST_DF.concat({'INCOME_NORMALIZED':(CUST_DF['INCOME'] - income_mean)/income_std})

z.show(CUST_DF[['INCOME', 'INCOME_NORMALIZED']].head().round(4))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Normalize INCOME using min-max scaling
paragraphs.text:
%python

income_min = CUST_DF['INCOME'].min()
income_max = CUST_DF['INCOME'].max()

CUST_DF = CUST_DF.concat({'INCOME_MINMAX_SCALED': (CUST_DF['INCOME'] - income_min)/ (income_max - income_min)})
z.show(CUST_DF[['INCOME', 'INCOME_MINMAX_SCALED']].head().round(4))

paragraphs.title: Filter zero values from column TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS, then transform using base 10 logarithm

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Histogram on the original column
paragraphs.text:
%python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.style.use('seaborn')

plt.figure(figsize=[20,6])
oml.graphics.hist(CUST_DF['TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS'], bins=10, color='C0',
                 linestyle='solid', edgecolor='black')

plt.title('Histogram of original TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS')
plt.xlabel('TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS')
plt.ylabel('Customer Counts')
_ = plt.show()

%python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.style.use('seaborn')

plt.figure(figsize=[20,6])

C_FILT = CUST_DF_FILTERED.materialize()
oml.graphics.hist(C_FILT['LOG_TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS'], bins=10, color='C0',
                 linestyle='solid', edgecolor='black')

plt.title('Histogram of original LOG_TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS')
plt.xlabel('LOG_TOTAL_AUTOM_PAYMENTS')
plt.ylabel('Customer Counts')
_ = plt.show()
